awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Total Intervertebral Disc Replacement Device using Novel Energy Absorbing Materials.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project is to develop a prototype device aimed at improving the current standard of care for total disc replacement (TDR) procedures. Each year approximately $500,000 Americans will undergo surgery involving intervertebral disc replacement, resulting in a device market well over $1 billion. These procedures, which are most often interbody fusions or TDRs, are associated with a high rate of complications.  Approximately one-third of patients will ultimately require a follow-up procedure.  Although the underlying causes are unclear, the biomedical devices most often used are significantly stiffer than the original intervertebral disc, and no cushioning or force dissipation occurs across the disc space; this is likely a significant factor for complications such as subsidence and adjacent level disease. This study will be the first cyclic loading investigation into the use of novel liquid crystalline elastomers (LCEs) for potential use in spinal devices. If successful, the proposed research will develop LCEs for stable long-term mechanical dissipative properties with a hierarchical structure to mimic the natural organization of the intervertebral disc. Other potential applications involving the use this ultra-dissipative material are for protective equipment used in sports or military, such as helmets to better prevent concussions. 


The proposed project will investigate main-chain LCEs, which have vastly superior energy dissipation properties relative to traditional rubber-like materials such as silicone or hydrogels. Liquid crystal mesogen reorientation under mechanical stress provides a temperature and frequency insensitive mechanism for dissipating energy, more robust than typical viscoelasticity. This proposed research will be the first to investigate cyclic mechanical properties of main-chain LCEs. The proposed research will result in an LCE proof-of-concept device that exhibits mechanical properties seen in biological soft tissues (i.e., anisotropy, dampening, and low modulus). The LCE will be synthesized a spatially tailored device to match the mechanical properties and structure of a natural disc. The unique liquid-crystal structure within these materials makes cyclic behavior difficult to estimate a priori, and therefore direct characterization as a function of material structure, strain rate, and displacement magnitude must be investigated. High-cycle loading of LCEs will be investigated. Fundamental knowledge gained through this analysis will show the feasibility of LCEs for TDR and demonstrate broad applicability of LCEs for dampening applications. This project builds directly from fundamental research discovery supported by the NSF.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded project sought to develop a total disc replacement (TDR) device to aid in the treatment and mitigation of degenerative disc disease. This disease affects millions of Americans every year and costs the healthcare system billions of dollars. The disease can be painful and debilitating, reducing range of motion and eventually affecting quality of life. Fortunately, many solutions exist to treat degenerative disc disease, but none are without compromise. A total spinal fusion remains the most common remedy today. This procedure mechanically fuses two vertebrae together, at the expense some functionality. The procedure is relatively successful, has good patient outcomes for reducing pain, but comes at the expense of patient mobility. Furthermore, rates of revision surgeries can be high, often due to adjacent segment disease (failure of the neighboring vertebrae). More recent procedures involve a total disc replacement. These artificial discs are intended to imitate actual biological tissue in both form and function. Ideally, a total disc replacement has similar reduction in pain compared to a fusion procedure but without the corresponding loss in patient mobility.

 

The spinal disc is made of two unique tissues that serve different purposes. The nucleus pulposus fills the central region of the disc, is relatively soft, and provides mechanical damping and cushion during compression. The annulus fibrosus surrounds the edge of the disc and is much stiffer compared to the nucleus pulposus. The annulus fibrosus provides the necessary support and structure to the disc. Liquid crystalline elastomers are a special class of polymer with unique directional properties that make them well suited to mimic the properties of both the nucleus pulposus and annulus fibrosus. The focus of this grant was to research the material behavior, fabrication methods, and biological response necessary to evaluate the potential of LCEs as a biomaterial with applications for an artificial spinal disc.

 

Ultimately, this research resulted in the publication of several peer-reviewed works. In these works the mechanical behavior of LCEs was evaluated. There are two common polymeric structures relevant to LCEs. The first is the polydomain structure. This network morphology has an overall random structure and thus the mechanical response is the same in all directions. Monodomain networks include the global alignment of the microscopic liquid crystals. The monodomain alignment has highly directional behavior. When load is applied transverse to the alignment the material is very stiff. When load is applied with the alignment, the material is very soft with enhanced damping and dissipation. Testing revealed that the polydomain LCE material has similar damping behavior in shear loads to the nucleus pulposus. Under compressive loads, it was found that the monodomain material reasonably mimics the annulus fibrosus when load was applied transverse to the alignment. Ultimately, a proof of concept device was fabricated that positively bonded a ring of monodomain material around a core of cast polydomain LCE material. Cyclic loads are common in most biomechanical applications, and thus became the focus of another research direction. Cyclic loading of LCE materials revealed that the stability of the material is highly dependent on both temperature and loading rate and these parameters must be accounted for during the device design process. Much mechanical testing on the concept device remains to be done and is being actively pursued.

 

Other work performed involved evaluating the subcutaneous biological response of LCE materials. Subcutaneous implantation in rats revealed the material is mostly inert. No inflammation and minimal fibrous encapsulation occurred during the implantation period. Work was also done to evaluate the unique behavior of LCEs at and around body temperature. Through careful tuning of the chemical makeup it was possible to shift the glass transition temperature closer to body temperature and optimize desirable behaviors. Finally, advanced fabrication methods have been investigated to manufacture the intricate geometries that will likely be necessary for a biomedical device. Much success has been made towards 3D printing LCE materials through a direct ink write method followed by immediate subsequent UV polymerization. Geometries have been printed that would not be possible through traditional casting methods, and alignment of the liquid crystals during printing is also possible. Ultimately, much further work in this are remains to be performed, but results thus far are very  promising.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/24/2021
Modified by: Carl P Frick
